title: What is a Variable? (The Labeled Box)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you have empty boxes in a warehouse, and you need to store things in them. Each box gets a LABEL (like 'Books' or 'Toys') so you know what's inside.

Variables are exactly like labeled boxes! They're containers that store information in your program:

• The LABEL is the variable name (like 'playerScore' or 'userName')
• The CONTENTS are the value stored inside (like 100 or 'Alex')
• You can look inside the box anytime by using its label
• You can replace what's inside by putting new stuff in!

In C#, before you can use a box, you must tell the computer: "I need a box for storing text" or "I need a box for storing numbers." This is called DECLARING a variable.

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: 'string' means this box holds TEXT. 'playerName' is the label on the box. The semicolon ends the statement.
The = sign means 'put this value INTO the box'. We're storing the text 'Alex' in our playerName box.
No quotes around playerName! That tells C# to look INSIDE the box and get the value, not just display the word 'playerName'.

challenge.instructions:
Create a program that:
1. Declares a variable called 'favoriteGame'
2. Stores YOUR favorite game in it
3. Displays a message like: 'My favorite game is [your game]'
4. Changes the variable to a different game
5. Displays the new game
challenge.hint: Remember: string variableName; creates the box. variableName = "value"; puts something in it. Use the variable name WITHOUT quotes in Console.WriteLine!
commonStickingPoints: Putting quotes around the variable name when using it: Console.WriteLine("favoriteGame") displays the word 'favoriteGame', not the value!
Forgetting to declare the variable first: You must write 'string favoriteGame;' before you can use it!
Misspelling the variable name: 'favoriteGame' and 'favoritegame' are different! C# is case-sensitive!
